question: [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Struct: BuildVersionCheckerConfig] [Deserialization attack] Can an attacker provide malicious JSON configuration with crafted fields that bypass the #[serde(deny_unknown_fields)] attribute through nested objects, allowing injection of unexpected configuration values that could alter checker behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Struct: BuildVersionCheckerConfig] [Configuration injection] Does the #[serde(flatten)] on CommonCheckerConfig (line 28) allow attackers to override critical 'required' field values through configuration manipulation, potentially disabling mandatory security checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Struct: BuildVersionCheckerConfig] [Type confusion] Can an attacker exploit serde's type coercion during deserialization to inject non-boolean values into the CommonCheckerConfig.required field through numeric or string representations, bypassing validation logic? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Struct: BuildVersionCheckerConfig] [Memory exhaustion] Is there a limit on the size of configuration JSON being deserialized? Can an attacker provide extremely large configuration payloads causing memory exhaustion and DoS during serde deserialization? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Struct: BuildVersionCheckerConfig] [Clone trait abuse] The Clone trait on BuildVersionCheckerConfig (line 25) - can attackers exploit shared references through cloning to cause race conditions when multiple threads access mutable config state simultaneously? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: new()] [Initialization bypass] Does the new() constructor (lines 39-41) perform any validation on the BuildVersionCheckerConfig? Can an attacker pass a maliciously crafted config with invalid CommonCheckerConfig.required values to disable security checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: new()] [Object lifecycle] Is there thread-safety validation in new()? Can multiple concurrent calls to new() with the same config reference cause undefined behavior through shared mutable state? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: new()] [Resource leak] Does new() allocate any resources that need cleanup? If the BuildVersionChecker instance is dropped before use, are there potential resource leaks or dangling references? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: get_build_commit_hash()] [Key injection] The BUILD_COMMIT_HASH_KEY constant (line 23) is used directly in get_value() - can an attacker manipulate the SystemInformation HashMap to inject malicious keys that match this constant but contain exploitable data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: get_build_commit_hash()] [Information disclosure] Does get_build_commit_hash() (lines 43-59) expose sensitive system information through the evaluation_on_missing_fn closure that could leak node internals to unauthorized parties monitoring CheckResult outputs? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: get_build_commit_hash()] [Closure exploitation] The evaluation_on_missing_fn closure (lines 44-53) calls Self::build_result - can an attacker trigger conditions where this closure is called repeatedly causing resource exhaustion through excessive CheckResult allocations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: get_build_commit_hash()] [Format string injection] The format! macro in evaluation_on_missing_fn (lines 48-51) includes BUILD_COMMIT_HASH_KEY - can an attacker manipulate this constant or inject format specifiers to cause format string vulnerabilities? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: get_build_commit_hash()] [Score manipulation] The hardcoded score of 0 (line 47) for missing build hash - can an attacker exploit this fixed scoring to manipulate overall node health assessment by controlling when system_information lacks this key? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: get_build_commit_hash()] [String allocation DoS] Does get_value() perform string cloning of the hash value? Can an attacker provide extremely long build_commit_hash strings causing memory exhaustion through repeated string allocations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: get_build_commit_hash()] [Null byte injection] Can the build_commit_hash value contain null bytes or special characters that could cause string truncation or injection vulnerabilities in downstream processing? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Provider substitution] The get_provider! macro (lines 69-78) retrieves baseline and target providers - can an attacker substitute malicious provider implementations in the ProviderCollection to return fake system information bypassing version validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [TOCTOU race] Between baseline_provider.provide() (line 80) and target_provider.provide() (line 81), can an attacker modify the provider state causing time-of-check-time-of-use vulnerabilities where validation passes but actual values differ? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Macro expansion attack] Does the get_provider! macro properly validate the required parameter (self.config.common.required)? Can attackers exploit macro expansion to inject malicious code or bypass the required check? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Provider cache poisoning] SystemInformationProvider uses OutputCache (from system_information.rs) - can an attacker poison the cache with malicious build_commit_hash values that persist across multiple check() invocations, causing false validation results? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Async cancellation] The async fn check() (lines 65-143) - if the Future is cancelled mid-execution between baseline and target provider calls, can this leave inconsistent state or cause resource leaks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Error suppression] When target_provider.provide() fails (lines 81-90), the error is caught and converted to CheckResult with score 0 - can attackers intentionally trigger provider failures to suppress legitimate version mismatch detection? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Error message injection] The error formatting in line 87 uses {:#} format - can attackers control the error content from target_provider to inject malicious content into CheckResult explanations visible to operators? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Error handling bypass] For baseline node, GetValueResult::Missing returns CheckerError::MissingDataError (lines 96-102), but for target node it returns CheckResult (lines 107-110) - can attackers exploit this inconsistency to bypass baseline validation while hiding target issues? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Exception propagation] The early return on line 97 for baseline missing data - can attackers trigger this intentionally on baseline nodes to completely skip version checking and allow compromised target nodes to appear healthy? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/checker/build_version.rs] [Function: check()] [Key name injection] BUILD_COMMIT_HASH_KEY is used in the anyhow! macro (line 100) - can attackers modify this constant through unsafe code or memory corruption to change which metric is validated? (Critical)
